law.catch_line: A law enforcement agency may make a written request for the State's Attorney within the jurisdiction...

section.section:
On receipt of a request made under subsection (a)(1), (a)(2), (a)(3), or (a)(4) of this section, the State's Attorney:
if the warrant, summons, or other criminal process has remained unexecuted for more than 5 years but less than 7 years, may petition the Administrative Judge of the District for the invalidation and destruction of the unexecuted warrant, summons, or other process; and
if the warrant, summons, or other criminal process has remained unexecuted for at least 7 years, shall petition the Administrative Judge of the District for the invalidation and destruction of the unexecuted warrant, summons, or other process.

On receipt of a request made under subsection (a)(5) of this section, the State's Attorney shall petition the Administrative Judge of the District for the invalidation and destruction of the unexecuted warrant, summons, or other criminal process.

text.section: The State's Attorney may argue against the invalidation and destruction of the unexecuted warrant, summons, or other criminal process due to a justifiable continuing active investigation of the case.

Unless preservation is determined by the court to be justifiable, the court shall order the invalidation and destruction of an unexecuted warrant for a misdemeanor offense, summons, or other criminal process in accordance with § 1-605 of the Courts and Judicial Proceedings Article.
An arrest may not be made under the authority of a warrant or other criminal process that has been ordered invalidated and destroyed.
The State's Attorney may enter a nolle prosequi or place the case on the stet docket at the time of the court order under this section.

Nothing in this section may be construed to:
prevent the reissuance of a warrant, summons, or other criminal process;
affect the time within which a prosecution for a misdemeanor may be commenced; or
affect any pending criminal charge.
